instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A fan spinning very fast
threads.message: the board has very very little sign of water, but no component is oxidated or missing, the laptop works perfectly, any idea where to start?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A fan spinning very fast
threads.message: If those are the only error first thing to try is another fan.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A fan spinning very fast
threads.message: (After trying new fan) Check that the fan plug is sitting in the socket correctly as if pin 2/3 not connecting it may run full check that the socket does not have broken pins 2 or 3 to the board. Check resistance of <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> (100k), <RESISTOR>R6065</RESISTOR> (47k), <RESISTOR>R6060</RESISTOR> (47k) (page 45 of schematic) check continuity and shorts to ground in this area - could be <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> not controlling properly. Had very similar problem (and ASD results) on an iMac recently and it was one of those resistors that someone had knocked off the board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A fan spinning very fast
